predictions.text: U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) will publish formal implementation guidance (CSMS message and/or Federal Register notice) establishing collection procedures and an effective date for a new broadly applied 10% tariff on most U.S. imports (a near-universal additional duty), consistent with the announced “10% global tariff.”
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves YES if CBP issues a CSMS message or Federal Register notice by 2026-03-31 that (i) explicitly describes a new generally applicable additional duty rate of 10% (or “additional 10%”) on a wide set of imports and (ii) provides an effective date and collection/entry instructions. Otherwise NO.
evidence: Trump announced a new 10% global tariff after the Supreme Court tariff ruling (CNBC, 2026-02-20): https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/20/trump-global-trade-tariff-supreme-court.html
Supreme Court struck down prior “reciprocal” tariffs, reshaping constraints but leaving policy uncertainty (BBC live page): https://www.bbc.com/news/live/c0l9r67drg7t
monitoring_signals: CBP CSMS announcements mentioning “additional duties,” “10%,” “surcharge,” or “universal tariff”
Federal Register notices for Presidential Proclamations / tariff actions and HTSUS changes
USTR/White House fact sheets specifying scope and effective dates
predictions.rationale: If a broad tariff is intended to be real (not just signaling), importers need CBP entry instructions quickly; formal CBP guidance is typically required to operationalize collection.

predictions.text: At least one major U.S. trading partner (EU, Canada, Mexico, China, Japan, or South Korea) will officially announce retaliatory trade measures specifically in response to the U.S. “10% global tariff,” covering at least $10 billion (USD) of annual U.S.-origin goods (value stated in the announcement or accompanying government documentation).
predictions.verification_criteria: YES if by 2026-06-30 an eligible government publishes an official retaliation announcement (press release, gazette, regulation, or equivalent) explicitly tied to the U.S. 10% global tariff and stating coverage of ≥$10B/year (USD equivalent) of U.S.-origin goods (or providing a list plus an official value estimate meeting the threshold). Otherwise NO.
evidence: New U.S. 10% global tariff announcement increases escalation/retaliation risk (CNBC, 2026-02-20): https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/20/trump-global-trade-tariff-supreme-court.html
monitoring_signals: European Commission DG TRADE countermeasure announcements
Canada Department of Finance / Global Affairs Canada tariff retaliation notices
China MOFCOM statements and tariff schedules
WTO dispute filings referencing the U.S. measure
predictions.rationale: Broad U.S. tariffs often trigger politically necessary countermeasures; the $10B threshold avoids counting symbolic/limited actions.

predictions.text: The U.S. Monthly Treasury Statement will show gross Customs Duties receipts of at least $10.0 billion in at least one month (not seasonally adjusted).
predictions.verification_criteria: YES if any Monthly Treasury Statement published by 2026-08-31 reports the line item “Customs duties” (gross) ≥ $10.0B for a single month. Otherwise NO.
evidence: A new 10% global tariff was announced, which (if implemented) would tend to raise customs-duty receipts (CNBC, 2026-02-20): https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/20/trump-global-trade-tariff-supreme-court.html
monitoring_signals: Monthly Treasury Statement (MTS) releases and the Customs Duties line
CBP guidance indicating broad-based additional duty collection
Import volumes (Census trade data) and effective tariff-rate estimates from research groups
predictions.rationale: A broad tariff, even with some exemptions and behavioral response, should show up in federal cash receipts; $10B is a high but reachable monthly threshold if coverage is wide.

predictions.text: U.S. Core PCE inflation (PCE price index excluding food and energy, year-over-year) will print at or above 3.2% in at least one BEA monthly release.
predictions.verification_criteria: YES if any BEA Personal Income and Outlays release through 2026-08-31 shows Core PCE (ex food & energy) YoY ≥ 3.2% (as first reported, not revised). Otherwise NO.
evidence: Inflation firmed near ~3% while GDP growth softened, complicating the Fed outlook (CNBC, 2026-02-20): https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/20/pce-inflation-december-2025.html

Tariff uncertainty may delay or complicate price declines (MarketWatch, 2026-02-20): https://www.marketwatch.com/story/dont-expect-lower-prices-now-that-the-supreme-court-ruled-against-trumps-tariffs-7334f6c9
monitoring_signals: BEA Core PCE YoY monthly prints and three-/six-month annualized rates
Import price indices and goods inflation components
Survey-based inflation expectations and tariff pass-through commentary from retailers
predictions.rationale: With inflation already sticky near 3% and tariff-related pass-through risks, a ≥3.2% core print is plausible within the next two quarters.

predictions.text: The Federal Reserve will not cut the target range for the federal funds rate at any scheduled FOMC meeting concluding on or before 2026-06-30 (i.e., the upper bound will be unchanged vs its level on 2026-02-19).
predictions.verification_criteria: YES if all FOMC decisions at meetings ending on/before 2026-06-30 leave the target range unchanged relative to the range in effect on 2026-02-19 (no 25bp+ cut). Otherwise NO.
evidence: Sticky inflation near ~3% alongside weaker growth complicates the Fed path (CNBC, 2026-02-20): https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/20/pce-inflation-december-2025.html
New tariff announcement raises renewed inflation-risk uncertainty (CNBC, 2026-02-20): https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/20/trump-global-trade-tariff-supreme-court.html
monitoring_signals: CME FedWatch probabilities for near-term meetings
Core PCE and CPI trend vs 2% target
FOMC statements/minutes references to tariff-related inflation risks
predictions.rationale: Near-term cuts are less likely when inflation is sticky and policy uncertainty is rising; waiting through midyear is a common pattern in such regimes.

predictions.text: New York Fed’s Quarterly Report on Household Debt and Credit will report the student-loan balance delinquency rate (90+ days past due) at or above 13.0% in at least one release.
predictions.verification_criteria: YES if any NY Fed Household Debt and Credit report released by 2026-11-30 shows student loans 90+ days delinquent (as a share of student-loan balances) ≥ 13.0%. Otherwise NO.
evidence: Reported student-loan delinquency nearing 25% signals rising household credit stress (CNBC, 2026-02-20): https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/20/student-loan-delinquency.html
monitoring_signals: NY Fed Household Debt and Credit quarterly releases (student-loan delinquency chart/table)
CFPB/Ed Department statements on repayment and delinquency dynamics
Bank/servicer earnings commentary on education-loan performance
predictions.rationale: As repayment normalization continues and household balance sheets face pressure, a higher 90+ day delinquency share is a plausible tail-risk outcome.

predictions.text: The European Union will approve (by European Council/ECOFIN decision or EU legal act) a new Ukraine financing package involving EU-level borrowing/guaranteed issuance with a headline size of at least €50 billion.
predictions.verification_criteria: YES if by 2026-09-30 an official EU decision/legal act is adopted establishing a Ukraine financing facility that explicitly includes EU-level borrowing or EU-guaranteed bond issuance with total envelope ≥ €50B. Otherwise NO.
evidence: Hungary is an obstacle to Europe’s proposed large loan to Ukraine, highlighting unanimity constraints and delay risk (NYT, 2026-02-20): https://www.nytimes.com/2026/02/20/world/europe/euro-loan-ukraine-hungary-obstacle.html
monitoring_signals: European Council conclusions and ECOFIN communiqués on Ukraine financing
European Commission proposals and adopted regulations/decisions
Public statements by Hungary and other member states on veto/conditions
predictions.rationale: Despite unanimity hurdles, Ukraine funding needs and political pressure make eventual approval of a large EU-level instrument plausible over a ~6–8 month window.

predictions.text: The S&P 500 Index (SPX) will close at least 15% below its 2026-02-21 official close on at least one trading day.
predictions.verification_criteria: YES if SPX official closing value on any date through 2026-08-31 is ≤ 0.85 × (SPX close on 2026-02-21). Otherwise NO.
evidence: Trade-policy shifts and tariff uncertainty elevate macro/earnings risks (BBC live page): https://www.bbc.com/news/live/c0l9r67drg7t
Sticky inflation with weaker growth complicates policy and risk assets (CNBC, 2026-02-20): https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/20/pce-inflation-december-2025.html

Private credit stress signals raise concerns about broader financial conditions (CNBC, 2026-02-20): https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/20/canary-in-the-coal-mine-blue-owl-liquidity-curbs-fuel-fears-private-credit-bubble-.html
monitoring_signals: SPX level vs the 0.85 drawdown threshold
Credit spreads and VIX spikes
Earnings revisions and tariff-related margin commentary
predictions.rationale: Tariff shocks, sticky inflation, and tightening financial conditions can plausibly produce a mid-year equity drawdown of this magnitude.

predictions.text: S&P Global LCD will report the U.S. leveraged-loan trailing-12-month default rate at or above 4.0% in at least one monthly update.
predictions.verification_criteria: YES if any S&P Global LCD monthly default-rate publication through 2026-12-31 shows the U.S. leveraged-loan LTM default rate ≥ 4.0% (issuer-weighted or volume-weighted as presented by LCD). Otherwise NO.
evidence: Private credit/liquidity-curb concerns indicate stress in leveraged lending ecosystems (CNBC, 2026-02-20): https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/20/canary-in-the-coal-mine-blue-owl-liquidity-curbs-fuel-fears-private-credit-bubble-.html
monitoring_signals: S&P Global LCD default-rate trackers and distressed ratio
Refinancing calendar maturity walls and loan repricing activity
High-yield/loan spread movements and covenant-lite recovery commentary
predictions.rationale: If growth slows while rates remain high, refinance stress can lift defaults toward levels consistent with late-cycle credit conditions.

predictions.text: Microsoft and/or OpenAI will announce a new U.S.-located AI data-center campus/project with either (a) planned site power capacity of at least 1.0 GW or (b) disclosed project capex of at least $20 billion.
predictions.verification_criteria: YES if by 2026-12-31 Microsoft or OpenAI issues a press release/blog post or is quoted in a major outlet (with attributable company confirmation) announcing a U.S. AI data-center project and explicitly stating ≥1.0 GW planned power capacity or ≥$20B capex. Otherwise NO.
evidence: OpenAI told investors compute spend could approach $600B by 2030, implying massive infrastructure buildout (CNBC, 2026-02-20): https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/20/openai-resets-spend-expectations-targets-around-600-billion-by-2030.html
Oxford battery advance highlights accelerating energy/storage/compute infrastructure competition (ScienceDaily, 2026-02-20): https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2026/02/260220010830.htm
monitoring_signals: Microsoft/OpenAI announcements with hyperscale site details
State/local permitting, incentive agreements, and utility interconnection filings citing GW-scale loads
Power purchase agreements (PPAs) and transmission upgrades linked to AI campuses
predictions.rationale: Publicly disclosed GW-scale campuses are increasingly common for hyperscalers; OpenAI/Microsoft scale targets make at least one such U.S. announcement plausible within a year.
